ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I learned how to
- use common Russian expressions and their corresponding idioms
- form sentences with numerals
- answer questions spontaneously and deliver presentations in Russian
- discuss historical events in Russian

Continued developing Russian grammar, listening, reading, writing skills; lots of emphasis on understanding and internalizing readings about Russian imperial history (this gives a very solid vocabulary foundation for students who are learning the language that are interested in IR, history, politics, etc.); advanced grammar topics covered like oblique numbers, participles/gerunds, perfective vs imperfective, commands (warning: this stuff is actually way more complicated than the way its taught in intro courses!)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- Detailed and meticulous overviews of each topic by the professor
- Clear grading structure with fair quizzes and tests
- Plenty of opportunities to speak aloud
- An incomparable textbook written by the professor with notes, a bibliography, and grammatical exercises
Weaknesses:
- Professor tends to fall into English quickly

Strengths: Professor Muravnik is a great guy. Super knowledgeable about Russian history/politics and very encouraging during class. TA was great. The   (lunch with professor/TA) were very fun. The readings are actually super interesting, and you leave the class with a much more comprehensive view of Russian Imperial history from the time of Catherine the Great to Nicholas I (all in Russian!). || Weaknesses: a more clear grading rubric from the start? (though this isn't really a big deal)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: As with any language course, the recommendation is based on the student's level. For a student of high language capability, this course is disappointing at times because of the frequency of English conversations. For students of a low language capability, the course might be excessively challenging because the textbook is filled with difficult historical concepts. I personally found it fulfilling and especially appreciated the many opportunities to speak aloud, both for recordings and for oral presentations/assessments.

Yes, if you are trying to improve your Russian and have the time to invest in it. While what we learn in class is cool, in order for the material to really stick (at a level which actually improves your language ability), one would need to put in many many hours a week drilling vocab/grammar. If a student is committed to doing this, then they should definitely take this class. With that amount of time put in, it will be stress-free and you would get a lot out of it. Prof Muravnik is a fantastic and knowledgeable Professor, and he's very good at explaining very complex grammatical concepts.
